item.title: Saffron Milk During Pregnancy: Benefits, Safety, and Best Practices
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Discover if saffron milk is safe during pregnancy. Learn about its health benefits, recommended intake, potential risks, and preparation tips for expecting mothers.
item.content:encoded:
Every culture has its time-honored remedies for nurturing a healthy pregnancy, and few are as celebrated or as aromatic as saffron milk. While modern medicine plays a crucial role in prenatal care, ancient remedies still hold value for many expecting mothers. Among them, saffron milk, a golden-hued, aromatic drink steeped in tradition.

But how safe is it during pregnancy? Can a few strands of this luxurious spice truly benefit you and your baby?

This article blends time-honored wisdom with scientific research to uncover the truth about saffron milk during pregnancy.

What Is Saffron Milk?

Saffron milk, often called kesar doodh, is a warm beverage made by infusing milk with a few strands of saffron. It may include other ingredients like cardamom, almonds, or turmeric, depending on cultural or personal preferences. Saffron, derived from the Crocus sativus flower, is the world’s most expensive spice by weight, prized for its distinctive aroma, vibrant color, and therapeutic properties.

Traditionally used in Ayurvedic medicine, saffron milk is believed to boost immunity, improve complexion, and uplift mood. But during pregnancy, its benefits and risks warrant closer examination.

Is Saffron Milk Safe During Pregnancy?

Saffron Milk During Pregnancy: Benefits, Safety, and Best Practices

Yes, saffron milk can be safe during pregnancy when consumed in moderation. The key is dosage. While saffron offers several potential health benefits, excessive intake may lead to uterine contractions, especially in the first trimester.

Most healthcare professionals and nutritionists recommend limiting saffron consumption to 2 to 3 strands per day steeped in milk, particularly after the first trimester. The spice is potent, and more is not always better.

As always, it’s essential to consult your OB-GYN before adding any herbal or traditional remedies to your prenatal routine, especially if you have underlying health conditions.

Nutritional Benefits of Saffron Milk Rich in Antioxidants

Saffron contains powerful antioxidants like crocin, safranal, and kaempferol. These compounds help neutralize free radicals in the body, which can reduce inflammation and boost overall immunity.

Promotes Healthy Digestion

Digestive discomfort, including bloating and constipation, is common during pregnancy. Saffron has carminative properties that may soothe the digestive tract and improve metabolism when consumed in small quantities.

Supports Emotional Well-being and Reduces Stress

Hormonal fluctuations during pregnancy can affect mood. Saffron is known for its mild antidepressant effects and can help improve mood and reduce symptoms of anxiety and stress.

Clinical studies suggest saffron supplementation may even help with mild to moderate depression.

May Help with Blood Pressure Regulation

Some studies suggest saffron may support cardiovascular health by helping to regulate blood pressure and improve circulation. This is particularly helpful during pregnancy when blood volume increases and maintaining healthy blood pressure becomes crucial.

Cultural Beliefs Around Saffron in Pregnancy

In many Indian, Persian, and Middle Eastern cultures, saffron milk is traditionally believed to promote a fair complexion in babies, a belief not supported by science. However, its use in pregnancy is culturally linked to enhancing vitality, calming the mind, and nurturing the mother.

While these beliefs persist, modern healthcare professionals emphasize its nutritional rather than cosmetic value.

Potential Risks of Saffron Milk During Pregnancy Overconsumption and Uterine Contractions

Saffron in high doses (more than 5 grams) is considered unsafe and may stimulate uterine contractions, potentially leading to preterm labor or miscarriage. Always stick to small quantities, just 2 to 3 strands per serving.

Allergic Reactions

Though rare, saffron can trigger allergic reactions in some individuals, including dry mouth, dizziness, or nausea. Discontinue use and consult your doctor if any symptoms appear.

Impact on Blood Pressure for Sensitive Individuals

While saffron can help stabilize blood pressure, in some cases, it may cause slight drops. If you are prone to low blood pressure, discuss this with your healthcare provider before use.

Best Time to Drink Saffron Milk During Pregnancy

Saffron Milk During Pregnancy: Benefits, Safety, and Best Practices

Evening is often ideal, as saffron’s calming properties may help with better sleep. It can be introduced safely during the second trimester and continued in moderation through the third.

FAQs 1. Can saffron milk help with pregnancy mood swings?

Yes, saffron has natural mood-lifting properties and may help reduce anxiety and emotional stress during pregnancy.

2. Is it safe to drink saffron milk daily during pregnancy?

Yes, but only in small amounts—2–3 strands of saffron per day is the safe recommended limit.

3. When should I start drinking saffron milk while pregnant?

It’s best to start in the second trimester after consulting with your OB-GYN.

4. Does saffron milk affect baby’s complexion?

No, there is no scientific evidence that saffron influences skin color. Its benefits are nutritional and emotional.

5. How many saffron strands are safe to use during pregnancy?

Stick to 2–3 strands per day steeped in milk. Avoid excess to prevent adverse effects.

A Golden Elixir in Moderation

Saffron milk during pregnancy can be a warm, soothing, and nutritious addition to your diet provided it’s consumed responsibly. Rich in antioxidants, known for calming the nerves, and steeped in tradition, this luxurious spice offers more than just flavor.

Keep the dosage low, choose high-quality saffron, and always seek medical advice if unsure. As with many things in pregnancy, balance is everything.

item.title: Is Oat Milk Good for Pregnancy? Nutritional Benefits & Expert Advice
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Discover if oat milk is safe during pregnancy. Explore its nutritional benefits, potential risks, and expert tips for expecting mothers in this comprehensive guide.
item.content:encoded:
When you’re expecting, every bite and sip you take matters. From morning sickness to late-night cravings, pregnancy comes with its own set of nutritional puzzles. Among the growing range of plant-based alternatives, oat milk has quickly risen as a favorite. But is oat milk good for pregnancy?

If you’re curious about whether this creamy, dairy-free drink belongs in your prenatal diet, you’re not alone. Let’s explore how oat milk stacks up nutritionally, what benefits it offers for mom and baby, and what experts have to say.

Nutritional Benefits of Oat Milk During Pregnancy

Is Oat Milk Good for Pregnancy? Nutritional Benefits & Expert Advice

Oat milk brings a lot to the table especially for moms-to-be looking for a gentle, lactose-free milk option.

1. High in Fiber for Digestive Support

Pregnancy often slows digestion, leading to bloating and constipation. Oat milk, rich in soluble fiber like beta-glucan, promotes regular bowel movements and a healthy gut.

2. Fortified with Essential Nutrients

Most commercial oat milk brands are fortified with:

Calcium and Vitamin D: For fetal bone development

Vitamin B12: Supports neurological health

Folic Acid: Reduces risk of neural tube defects

3. Heart-Healthy and Low in Saturated Fat

Oat milk contains heart-supporting compounds like beta-glucans and is naturally low in saturated fats and cholesterol, making it a heart-smart choice during pregnancy.

4. Gentle on the Stomach and Allergen-Friendly

Oat milk is lactose-free, making it suitable for women with dairy intolerance. It’s also a safe option for those with soy or nut allergies, provided it’s certified gluten-free if needed.

Potential Drawbacks and Considerations

Despite its many benefits, oat milk isn’t perfect.

1. Lower in Protein

Compared to dairy or soy milk, oat milk has less protein. Ensure you’re supplementing with other protein-rich foods like legumes, eggs, or lean meats.

2. Watch for Added Sugars

Some flavored oat milks contain high levels of added sugar. Opt for unsweetened, fortified versions to keep your sugar intake in check.

3. Gluten Cross-Contamination

Though oats are naturally gluten-free, contamination can occur. If you’re gluten-sensitive, make sure to choose certified gluten-free oat milk.

Expert Recommendations

Is Oat Milk Good for Pregnancy? Nutritional Benefits & Expert Advice

Registered dietitians and obstetricians generally agree that oat milk is safe and beneficial during pregnancy when consumed in moderation. One to two servings per day can comfortably fit into a well-rounded prenatal diet, especially when using fortified brands.

FAQs 1. Can I drink oat milk every day while pregnant?

Yes, up to 1–2 servings daily of fortified, unsweetened oat milk is generally considered safe and beneficial.

2. Is oat milk safe in the first trimester?

Yes, its gentle nature and folic acid content support early fetal development and digestion.

3. Does oat milk have enough calcium for pregnancy?

Fortified oat milk typically contains similar calcium levels to cow’s milk. Always check the label.

4. Is oat milk good for gestational diabetes?

Unsweetened oat milk may be suitable due to its fiber content, but always consult your doctor.

5. Can oat milk cause bloating during pregnancy?

It’s generally easy to digest, but those sensitive to fiber or gluten should choose carefully.

A Comforting Choice With Nutritional Merit

So, is oat milk good for pregnancy? 100% YES, when chosen wisely. Its fiber content, fortification with essential nutrients, and smooth, comforting texture make it a wonderful addition to many prenatal diets. Just be mindful of added sugars and pair it with protein-rich foods to round out your nutrition.

As always, consult your healthcare provider to tailor your choices to your unique needs. With a little care, oat milk can be more than just a dairy alternative. It can be a nourishing companion on your journey to motherhood.

item.title: Is Soy Milk Good for Pregnancy? Benefits, Safety & Expert Advice
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Discover if soy milk is safe and beneficial during pregnancy. Learn about its nutrients, potential risks, and expert tips for expecting mothers.
item.content:encoded:
Pregnancy is a time of profound transformation, not only for your body but also for your lifestyle and dietary habits. With countless food and drink options vying for your attention, it’s natural to wonder: Is soy milk good for pregnancy?

As plant-based diets grow in popularity, many expecting mothers are turning to alternatives like soy milk.

This article breaks down the nutritional benefits, potential concerns, and expert recommendations to help you make an informed, confident choice for both you and your baby.

Understanding Soy Milk: What Is It?

Soy milk is a plant-based beverage made from soaked, ground, and boiled soybeans. It is naturally lactose-free and often fortified with essential vitamins and minerals, making it a popular dairy substitute. For pregnant women, its high protein content and rich nutrient profile can offer considerable benefits.

Nutritional Benefits of Soy Milk During Pregnancy

Is Soy Milk Good for Pregnancy? Benefits, Safety & Expert Advice

High-Quality Plant-Based Protein

Protein is a building block of life, essential for fetal tissue development. Soy milk provides approximately 7 grams of protein per cup, which supports muscle growth, organ formation, and overall fetal health.

Rich in Essential Vitamins and Minerals

Calcium: Fortified soy milk can offer up to 300 mg of calcium per serving, crucial for developing strong bones and teeth in your baby.

Vitamin D: Supports calcium absorption and enhances immune function.

Folic Acid: Reduces the risk of neural tube defects during early pregnancy.

Vitamin B12: Vital for red blood cell production and neurological function.

Cholesterol-Free and Low in Saturated Fats

Heart health matters more than ever during pregnancy. Soy milk is naturally cholesterol-free and low in saturated fats, contributing to a healthier cardiovascular profile.

Common Concerns About Soy Milk in Pregnancy Isoflavones and Hormonal Effects

Soy contains isoflavones, plant compounds that mimic estrogen. Some worry these may affect hormonal balance during pregnancy. However, scientific evidence shows that moderate soy consumption does not pose a risk to maternal or fetal health.

Allergies and Sensitivities

Soy is one of the top eight allergens. If you have a soy allergy or experience symptoms like bloating or hives, it’s best to avoid soy milk and consult your healthcare provider for safe alternatives.

Choosing the Right Type of Soy Milk

Fortified: Look for products enriched with calcium, vitamin D, and B12.

Organic and Non-GMO: Reduces exposure to pesticides and genetically modified ingredients.

Unsweetened: Minimizes added sugar intake, helping control weight and blood sugar levels.

Expert Recommendations for Soy Milk Intake

Health professionals including the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and dietitians suggest that up to 1–2 servings of soy milk per day is safe and nutritious during pregnancy. It should be consumed as part of a varied and balanced prenatal diet.

How to Incorporate Soy Milk Into Your Pregnancy Diet

Is Soy Milk Good for Pregnancy? Benefits, Safety & Expert Advice

Use in smoothies with leafy greens and fruits for a vitamin-packed drink.

Replace dairy milk in oatmeal or cereal.

Use in baking or cooking for creaminess without lactose.

When to Avoid Soy Milk During Pregnancy

Avoid soy milk if you have a diagnosed soy allergy or have been advised by your healthcare provider to limit phytoestrogen intake. Always choose reputable brands and check labels for added sugars and additives.

FAQs 1. Can I drink soy milk every day during pregnancy?

Yes, drinking 1–2 servings of soy milk daily is generally safe and beneficial for pregnant women, provided it’s part of a balanced diet.

2. Is soy milk safe during the first trimester?

Yes, soy milk is safe in the first trimester and can support early fetal development due to its folic acid and protein content.

3. What are the alternatives to soy milk during pregnancy?

Almond milk, oat milk, and fortified rice milk are great alternatives if you are allergic to soy or prefer a different taste.

4. Does soy milk increase estrogen levels in pregnancy?

Soy contains phytoestrogens, but studies show that moderate consumption does not significantly affect estrogen levels in pregnant women.

5. Can soy milk cause miscarriage?

There is no scientific evidence linking moderate soy milk consumption to miscarriage. Always consult with your doctor for peace of mind.

Sip Smart, Stay Strong

So, is soy milk good for pregnancy? Absolutely! When chosen wisely and consumed in moderation, it can be a valuable part of a nourishing prenatal diet. Packed with plant-based protein, essential nutrients, and free from lactose, soy milk serves as a supportive ally in your pregnancy journey.

Just remember to consult your healthcare provider for personalized advice and opt for fortified, organic, unsweetened versions whenever possible.

Get ready, Singapore! Disney Jr. Live On Tour: Let’s Play! is bringing the magic of Mickey Mouse, Ariel the Little Mermaid, and Team Spidey to life in a spectacular live concert at the Singapore Indoor Stadium from 5 to 7 September 2025.

Designed especially for young children and their families, this interactive musical extravaganza promises six unforgettable shows packed with singing, dancing, colourful visuals, and beloved Disney Jr. characters. It’s the ultimate playdate adventure your kids won’t want to miss!

Event Details

Dates: Friday, 5 September to Sunday, 7 September 2025

Venue: Singapore Indoor Stadium

Showtimes:

Friday: 6:30 PM

Saturday: 10:30 AM, 2:30 PM, 6:30 PM

Sunday: 10:30 AM, 2:30 PM

Tickets: Available from Wednesday, 28 May at 10 AM via Ticketmaster Singapore: ticketmaster.sg/DisneyJrLive

Show Highlights

Star-Studded Cast: Join Mickey Mouse, Minnie Mouse, Ariel the Little Mermaid, the SuperKitties, the Puppy Dog Pals, and Team Spidey from “Marvel’s Spidey and his Amazing Friends” in a vibrant stage performance.

Interactive Experience: Get ready for singing, dancing, dazzling 3D visuals, and exciting acrobatics in this fully immersive live show.

Captivating Storyline: Mickey Mouse plans the ultimate playdate at the Clubhouse, but mysterious green weather threatens the fun. Team Spidey swings in to save the day and keep the playdate on track.

Musical Favourites: Enjoy hit songs from the Disney Jr. series, including:

“Hot Dog!” from “Mickey Mouse Clubhouse”

“Oopsie Kitty” from “SuperKitties”

“Do the Spidey” from “Marvel’s Spidey and his Amazing Friends”

Venue Information

The Singapore Indoor Stadium, located at 2 Stadium Walk, Singapore 397691, is a premier venue known for hosting major concerts and events. With a seating capacity of up to 12,000 for concerts, it offers state-of-the-art facilities to ensure an unforgettable experience.

Stay Connected

For the latest updates and behind-the-scenes content, follow the tour on social media:

Instagram: @DisneyJrTour

Facebook: Disney Jr. Tour

TikTok: @DisneyJrTour

Hashtag: #DisneyJrTour

item.title: ‘She’s Not Less, Just Simply Wired Differently’—A Singapore Mum Gets Real About Autism Parenting
item.dc:creator: Miko Pagaduan
item.description: Community is out there. And your child — just like Amelie — is more than their diagnosis.
item.content:encoded:
You never forget the moment your world shifts. For Benita, 43, that moment came quietly but decisively — not with a dramatic announcement, but during what was supposed to be a routine check-up at KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital. Her daughter Amelie, then just shy of three years old, had been admitted for a febrile seizure.

But something else caught the doctor’s attention.

When asked for her name, Amelie didn’t respond. She wasn’t engaging the way most children her age typically would.

That small interaction sparked a journey that would forever change how Benita saw her daughter — and herself. After a referral to a Developmental and Behavioural Paediatrician, the confirmation came.

Amelie was on the autism spectrum.

As a parent, you might find yourself grappling with the same storm of emotions. Denial. Guilt. Sleepless nights filled with questions. Benita did.

“I spent nights crying, questioning what had gone wrong — from my pregnancy to my parenting,” she recalls. “The diagnosis hit hard. There was guilt, fear, and deep uncertainty.”

Living With Autism is Not Less — Just Different

It’s okay to grieve the expectations you had. It’s okay to feel lost at first. But Benita wants you to know that a diagnosis of autism isn’t a life sentence. It’s a different roadmap. And it can be a gift. For her, receiving Amelie’s diagnosis brought not despair, but clarity.

“It gave me permission to understand and accept her for who she truly is, rather than trying to fit her into neurotypical milestones,” she shares.

That acceptance shifted everything. She stopped trying to correct behaviours like stimming or delayed responses. She began to build a parenting style that was structured yet loving, one that gave Amelie the predictability and clarity she needed to thrive.

As a parent, you might feel like you’re drowning in unknowns. But as Benita’s story shows, the journey through autism can become one of empowerment, understanding, and even joy.

“It took time to accept that Amelie was not “less,” but simply wired differently. “

When Support Systems Fall Short

In Singapore, early intervention services do exist — but they’re often hard to access. After Amelie’s diagnosis, Benita was advised to enrol her in government-provided therapy. What she quickly discovered was how limited those sessions were.

“Sometimes it was only once a quarter. It wasn’t enough,” she says. “We needed something more intensive.”

So she did what many parents in her position do: she became a researcher, advocate, and warrior — all in one. Books, podcasts, online searches — she left no stone unturned.

That’s how she found Bridging the Gap (BtG) in 2022. The multidisciplinary, integrated approach they offered was a breath of fresh air. For families looking for more than a piecemeal solution, BtG became a lifeline.

Source: BtG

The Cost of Care

If you’re raising a child with autism, you know the financial strain is real. Therapy, assessments, specialist consultations — they all add up. For Benita’s family of six, surviving on one income, it wasn’t easy.

“Budgeting for Amelie’s therapy was tough,” she says. But there was more than just the financial cost. There was the emotional one, too.

“I had to educate myself from scratch on what autism really meant,” she shares. “There’s no manual. You’re constantly learning, adapting, and sometimes, failing.”

But she kept going — driven by love, by hope, and by the strength of her support system.

Her husband, she says, has been her greatest pillar. Together, they’ve learned to lean on each other. And with BtG offering consistent, evidence-based care, they began to feel less alone.

Small Wins, Big Milestones

Since starting at BtG, Amelie’s progress has been profound. She’s more focused, communicates more clearly, and is learning to navigate the world with increasing independence.

“She can now balance on one foot, write with proper grip, and even wait safely to cross the road,” Benita shares proudly.

These may seem like small milestones to others — but to a parent of a child with autism, they are everything. They are hard-won, deeply cherished, and proof that early, holistic intervention makes a difference.

Autism and the Long Road to Emotional Endurance

As the years have passed, Benita has grown into her role as a caregiver with wisdom, patience, and emotional resilience. But the toll is real.

“It’s been a journey of joy, worry, exhaustion, and growth,” she admits.

If you’re in the thick of it right now, know this: you’re not weak for feeling tired. You’re not failing for needing help. And you deserve a support system that holds you up when you can’t do it alone. For Benita, that includes her husband, her community, and centres like BtG that walk this road with families every step of the way.

True Inclusion Starts With Us

Autism is not just a condition to be managed — it’s a way of seeing the world. And that world, Benita argues, needs to do better.

“True inclusion means recognising that every child — regardless of ability — deserves to be seen, supported, and accepted,” she says.

Buzzwords won’t change hearts. Actions will. Inclusion means training educators, redesigning public spaces, and most importantly, teaching our own children that different is not deficient.

If Amelie is to thrive in Singapore, we all need to make space for her — and others like her — to belong.

This Autistic Pride Day, Let’s Walk With Families Like Benita’s

Source: Adobe Stock

As Autistic Pride Day approaches on June 18, take a moment to reflect not just on the triumphs of the Autistic community, but also on the journey families like Benita’s have walked.

Autism isn’t something to fear — it’s something to understand.

If you’re a parent navigating this journey, know that you are not alone. Support is out there. Community is out there. And your child — just like Amelie — is more than their diagnosis. They are capable of growing, thriving, and teaching you a whole new way of seeing the world.

Take a breath. Ask for help. Tell your story. And most importantly — keep going.

Need support? Reach out to ECDA-recognised centres like Bridging the Gap. Because your journey matters — and you don’t have to walk it alone.

item.content:encoded:
Even though Singapore has one of the lowest maternal death rates in the world, cardiovascular disease is still one of the top causes of maternal deaths. With more women choosing to have kids later in life, it’s becoming even more important to look after heart health during pregnancy. Dr. Kua Jieli, an Interventional Cardiologist at Carrington Cardiology, shares expert tips on how to manage heart conditions during pregnancy and reduce long-term heart risks.

How Pregnancy Affects the Heart

During pregnancy, a woman’s body goes through a lot of changes to support the baby — especially the heart and blood vessels.

According to Dr. Kua, “Blood volume and the amount of blood the heart pumps go up by about 50%, while blood vessels relax and widen to help with flow, especially by the second trimester. The heart itself also changes; its size increases, and the main artery, the aorta, becomes more flexible.” These changes are caused by pregnancy hormones like oestrogen, progesterone, and relaxin, which also help the placenta grow and make sure the baby gets enough blood and nutrients.

For older mothers or women with pre-existing heart conditions, these changes can lead to complications like preeclampsia, stillbirth, early delivery, poor foetal growth, or heart problems during or after pregnancy, if not properly monitored.

Pregnancy Complications That Signal Future Heart Risk

Certain pregnancy complications serve as early indicators of heightened cardiovascular risk later in life. Dr. Kua identifies key conditions to watch for:

Preeclampsia

This is when a pregnant woman has high blood pressure and often protein in her urine. It’s linked to a 2 to 4 times higher risk of getting high blood pressure, heart disease, stroke, or heart failure in the future.

Gestational Hypertension

Gestational hypertension means high blood pressure that starts during pregnancy, but without protein in the urine. It may go away after delivery, but it can be an early sign that the woman might develop long-term high blood pressure or heart disease later on.

Gestational Diabetes

Gestational diabetes shows up during pregnancy but usually goes away afterwards. However, it raises the risk of getting type 2 diabetes, metabolic issues, and coronary artery disease down the road.

Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR)

This is when the baby grows too slowly in the womb. It may point to issues with the mother’s blood flow or placenta, and could be a sign of deeper heart or blood vessel problems.

Pre-Term Birth

Giving birth too early can be linked to inflammation and blood vessel problems, which increase the mum’s long-term risk of heart disease.

Stillbirth

Women who experience stillbirth have a higher long-term risk of heart disease, including stroke and myocardial infarction.

“These complications may act as a ‘stress test’ that reveals hidden problems with blood vessels or metabolism,” Dr. Kua emphasises.

Recognising Early Signs of Cardiovascular Issues During Pregnancy

Many early heart disease symptoms mirror typical pregnancy complaints and are often dismissed. Dr. Kua advises paying close attention to:

Chest pain

Fatigue

Light-headedness

Tachycardia rapid heart rate (>100 bpm)

Shortness of breath, especially at rest

Persistent cough

Swelling in the limbs

Frequent nighttime urination

“Symptoms can appear during pregnancy or up to a year postpartum. If persistent, they may indicate a life-threatening cardiovascular condition,” he cautions.

How Can Pregnant Women Manage Heart Disease?

Managing heart conditions during pregnancy requires a combination of proactive planning, vigilant monitoring, and a team-based medical approach. According to Dr. Kua Jieli, “Managing heart problems during pregnancy involves careful planning, close monitoring, and a collaborative, multidisciplinary approach to ensure the safety of both mother and baby.”

For women with pre-existing cardiac conditions, preconception counselling is crucial. Risk assessments using tools such as the WHO maternal cardiovascular classification can guide treatment plans. Dr. Kua emphasises that medications like ACE inhibitors, statins, and warfarin should be substituted with pregnancy-safe alternatives before conception.

Throughout pregnancy, routine tests such as echocardiograms and ECGs help monitor heart function. Physicians closely observe symptoms like palpitations, shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling, which may signal deterioration. Safe medications may include beta-blockers, low-dose diuretics for fluid control, and aspirin for preeclampsia risk reduction.

Dr. Kua notes, “Delivery planning must be individualized, although vaginal delivery is typically preferred unless contraindicated by cardiovascular status.” High-risk deliveries should occur in tertiary centres with cardiac support. Postpartum, the first six weeks are particularly critical, especially for patients with conditions like peripartum cardiomyopathy, necessitating continued monitoring.

Why is Postpartum Cardiovascular Screening Essential?

Despite the clear link between pregnancy complications and future cardiovascular disease (CVD), many postpartum programs omit heart health screening. Dr. Kua stresses that women with prior complications or existing heart disease must undergo routine assessments postpartum.

“A multidisciplinary care approach—starting from delivery and extending up to a year postpartum—can identify risks early and improve long-term outcomes,” he adds.

Common Myths About Pregnancy and Heart Health—Debunked

Misinformation can put maternal health at risk. Dr. Kua addresses prevalent myths:

“Pregnancy is a time to enjoy eating for two people.” While it’s true that pregnant women need more nutrition, it should never be to the point that they’re meeting the caloric needs for two people. Excessive weight gain can increase the risk of diabetes and heart disease. A balanced diet is key. Plan to gain only 2.3kg in the first half of pregnancy and 0.5kg per week thereafter.

“Eating spicy foods while pregnant can cause birth defects or harm the baby.” There is no evidence to suggest spicy foods can harm a developing foetus. But it may worsen heartburn, which can already be a problem during pregnancy.

“It is harmful to the baby when women sleep on their back.” There’s no need to panic if a pregnant woman ends up sleeping on her back — but there’s a bit of truth behind the concern. As the baby bump gets bigger, it can press down on a big vein called the inferior vena cava, which brings blood back to the heart. When this vein gets squashed, less blood flows back to the heart and around the body, including to the womb. This might make some women feel dizzy, sweaty, or even a bit nauseous.

“Keeping a pregnant woman’s heart rate lower than 140 bpm.” This outdated advice is no longer supported. Regular exercise won’t increase the risk of miscarriage, early delivery, or having a low birth weight baby. The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services actually recommends that pregnant women aim for about 150 minutes of moderate to intense exercise each week — and there’s no need to worry about sticking to a strict heart rate limit. However, it’s still important not to push yourself too hard.

What Are Preventive Measures to Avoid Heart Issues in Pregnant Women?

Preventive care is fundamental to reducing cardiovascular complications during pregnancy. A heart-healthy lifestyle—balanced nutrition, regular light-to-moderate exercise, and avoiding harmful substances like tobacco and alcohol—lays the groundwork for maternal well-being.

In addition to lifestyle, managing existing risk factors is essential. Conditions such as hypertension and diabetes must be controlled before and during pregnancy to prevent complications. Routine prenatal care allows early detection of warning signs, such as elevated blood pressure, which may indicate conditions like preeclampsia.

Education plays a pivotal role in prevention. Dr. Kua advises that women should seek immediate medical attention for “chest pain, severe breathlessness (especially at rest), rapid weight gain, palpitations, or episodes of fainting,” as these may indicate serious cardiovascular problems.

By empowering women with knowledge and ensuring timely medical intervention, many pregnancy-related heart complications can be mitigated or avoided altogether.

How Cardiologists and OB-GYNs Can Work Together

“Cardiologists and OB-GYNs can enhance maternal care by fostering a collaborative, multidisciplinary approach that begins before conception and extends well into the postpartum period.”

Starting with preconception counselling, It should include cardiovascular risk assessment, especially for those who are older, have high blood pressure, diabetes, or a history of heart problems

During pregnancy, doctors from different specialities can come together to create a joint care plan for women with heart issues, whether pre-existing or newly diagnosed. Regular updates between the teams help make sure treatments are adjusted when needed. For high-risk pregnancies, a team that includes maternal-foetal medicine specialists, cardiologists, and anaesthesiologists can work together to ensure safer delivery.

After giving birth, it’s still important to monitor heart health, as some conditions, like pregnancy-related heart conditions like peripartum cardiomyopathy or hypertension, can continue or even show up for the first time postpartum. Using shared health records, integrated care pathways, and joint clinics can help ensure mums get smooth, coordinated care at every stage.

Improving Healthcare Systems for Better Postpartum Heart Health

“Healthcare systems can enhance cardiovascular follow-up for postpartum women by emphasising the importance of a multidisciplinary, team-based approach to postpartum cardiovascular care.” Dr. Kua said.

This means cardiologists, OB-GYNs, maternal-foetal medicine specialists, and family doctors should all work closely together to make sure mums get smooth, continuous care from delivery to long-term heart management.

To prevent women with pregnancy-related heart risks from falling through the cracks, hospitals and clinics should set up structured referral systems and personalised follow-up plans. This includes identifying women who are more likely to face heart disease later and helping them manage things like high blood pressure, weight, cholesterol, and stress — especially in the first year after giving birth.

Healthcare professionals can also help by:

Doing standard heart health checks before discharge and during follow-up visits.

Using telehealth (video or phone consults) to make it easier for mums to attend appointments.

Using digital tools, like health apps or reminders, to stay connected with new mums and keep them engaged in their care.

All these steps can help make sure that mothers get the heart care they need — not just during pregnancy, but well after the baby is born.

ABOUT DR KUA JIELI

Dr. Kua Jieli is a Senior Consultant Cardiologist specialised in interventional cardiology and serves as the Medical Director at Carrington Cardiology. He has extensive experience in managing complex coronary artery disease and a wide range of cardiovascular conditions. His expertise includes performing advanced interventional procedures such as left main disease, chronic total occlusions, and heavily calcified lesions.

Preventive care is fundamental to reducing cardiovascular complications during pregnancy. A heart-healthy lifestyle—balanced nutrition, regular light-to-moderate exercise, and avoiding harmful substances like tobacco and alcohol—lays the groundwork for maternal well-being.
In addition to lifestyle, managing existing risk factors is essential. Conditions such as hypertension and diabetes must be controlled before and during pregnancy to prevent complications. Routine prenatal care allows early detection of warning signs, such as elevated blood pressure, which may indicate conditions like preeclampsia.
Education plays a pivotal role in prevention. Dr. Kua advises that women should seek immediate medical attention for “chest pain, severe breathlessness (especially at rest), rapid weight gain, palpitations, or episodes of fainting,” as these may indicate serious cardiovascular problems.
By empowering women with knowledge and ensuring timely medical intervention, many pregnancy-related heart complications can be mitigated or avoided altogether.
How Cardiologists and OB-GYNs Can Work Together
"Cardiologists and OB-GYNs can enhance maternal care by fostering a collaborative, multidisciplinary approach that begins before conception and extends well into the postpartum period."
Starting with preconception counselling, It should include cardiovascular risk assessment, especially for those who are older, have high blood pressure, diabetes, or a history of heart problems
During pregnancy, doctors from different specialities can come together to create a joint care plan for women with heart issues, whether pre-existing or newly diagnosed. Regular updates between the teams help make sure treatments are adjusted when needed. For high-risk pregnancies, a team that includes maternal-foetal medicine specialists, cardiologists, and anaesthesiologists can work together to ensure safer delivery.
After giving birth, it’s still important to monitor heart health, as some conditions, like pregnancy-related heart conditions like peripartum cardiomyopathy or hypertension, can continue or even show up for the first time postpartum. Using shared health records, integrated care pathways, and joint clinics can help ensure mums get smooth, coordinated care at every stage.
Improving Healthcare Systems for Better Postpartum Heart Health
"Healthcare systems can enhance cardiovascular follow-up for postpartum women by emphasising the importance of a multidisciplinary, team-based approach to postpartum cardiovascular care." Dr. Kua said.
This means cardiologists, OB-GYNs, maternal-foetal medicine specialists, and family doctors should all work closely together to make sure mums get smooth, continuous care from delivery to long-term heart management.
To prevent women with pregnancy-related heart risks from falling through the cracks, hospitals and clinics should set up structured referral systems and personalised follow-up plans. This includes identifying women who are more likely to face heart disease later and helping them manage things like high blood pressure, weight, cholesterol, and stress — especially in the first year after giving birth.
Healthcare professionals can also help by:

Doing standard heart health checks before discharge and during follow-up visits.

Using telehealth (video or phone consults) to make it easier for mums to attend appointments.

Using digital tools, like health apps or reminders, to stay connected with new mums and keep them engaged in their care.

All these steps can help make sure that mothers get the heart care they need — not just during pregnancy, but well after the baby is born.

Dr. Kua Jieli is a Senior Consultant Cardiologist specialised in interventional cardiology and serves as the Medical Director at Carrington Cardiology. He has extensive experience in managing complex coronary artery disease and a wide range of cardiovascular conditions. His expertise includes performing advanced interventional procedures such as left main disease, chronic total occlusions, and heavily calcified lesions.

item.title: This Dad Has Been Shaving His Head for 13 Years & He’s Not Stopping Anytime Soon
item.dc:creator: Miko Pagaduan
item.description: What started as a simple act of support soon turned into something much bigger.
item.content:encoded:
You’re probably familiar with Hair for Hope — the iconic annual campaign that sees brave souls across Singapore shaving their heads in solidarity with children battling cancer.

But have you ever wondered what keeps some people coming back year after year?

Meet Jason Ong. He’s a father of two, a consulting manager in the telecom industry, and one of Hair for Hope’s longest-running ambassadors. For 13 years, Jason has shaved, shared, rallied, and repeated — turning a single act of compassion into a lifelong mission to support families facing one of the toughest battles imaginable.

As Singapore celebrates its 60th birthday, the Children’s Cancer Foundation is spotlighting powerful human-interest stories to kick off Hair for Hope 2025.

And Jason’s journey is one worth hearing — not just for the legacy he’s built, but for the community he’s inspired along the way.

The First Shave and the Unexpected Chain Reaction

Jason first picked up the clippers back in 2008. What started as a simple act of support soon turned into something much bigger. Not only did he keep coming back to shave, but he also began organizing satellite events to grow the movement.

“When I first shaved, my kids were still very young. I don’t think they really understood what was going on,” he recalls.

But over time, the ritual became a teaching moment — a way to pass on values like empathy, resilience, and purpose. You know how it’s usually the organizers who chase people down? In Jason’s case, it was the opposite. His fellow “shavees” (yes, that’s a word) would beat him to the punch—emailing him months in advance to ask when the next satellite event was happening.

That’s when he knew: this wasn’t just a one-off effort. It had become a community.

“Each year when I shaved, I explained to them why I was doing it — to support children with cancer and their families.”

Source: Hair for Hope

38 June School Holiday Activities & Events for Kids

In 2010, when Jason organised his first Hair for Hope satellite event, he tried to get his son and daughter — then 10 and 8 years old — to join him on stage.

“I kept pressing them to shave, but they kept refusing,” he laughs.

Until one day, his son surprised him.

“Just before the event, he told me he wanted to shave. I asked him why he changed his mind, and he said a classmate had cancer — he wanted to support him. I was really touched. It meant the message had sunk in.”

That same day, Jason’s daughter joined her brother in solidarity.

“Both of them shaved at the first satellite event. My son continued into his secondary school years, and my daughter shaved again when she was 12 and 16. They’ve stopped shaving for now — they’re quite attached to their hair — but they still help out at events, ushering and setting up. They’re still part of the movement.”

Even as the kids grew older and stopped shaving their heads, they never stopped showing up. These days, they’re right there beside him at the events, helping with logistics—ushering guests, setting up stations, and quietly making things run smoothly behind the scenes.

What Keeps Jason Coming Back?

Motivation is a funny thing. You’d think after 13 years, the enthusiasm might fade. But for Jason, it’s only grown. When people around you believe in a cause so deeply that they nudge you about the next event, that’s something special.

Source: Hair for Hope

He’s seen the campaign evolve, watched his shavees return year after year, and built bonds with strangers who eventually became friends. That kind of community doesn’t just happen—it takes someone like Jason to make it stick.

And if you’re wondering what it’s like to shave your head for the first time, Jason gets the hesitation. Will the hair grow back the same? Will I look weird bald? Valid concerns. But as he likes to say, it’s worth doing at least once—if not for the look, then for the lesson.

More importantly, you’re showing children battling cancer that they’re not alone.

Source: Hair for Hope

Busting the Bald Myths

Let’s address the elephant in the room. Yes, shaving your head is a bold move. And no, it’s not a “get out of shampoo free” card.

“I know many people want to support, but they’re afraid,” he says. “Some worry their hair won’t grow back. Others worry they won’t look good bald.”

His advice? Give it a try — just once.

Source: Hair for Hope

Jason laughs about how people often assume shaving means less effort. But in reality, scalp care is still a thing—especially in sunny Singapore. Even with a smooth head, you’ll need proper washing, sunscreen, and yes, shampoo.

The key message? Don’t let vanity or myths hold you back from doing something good.

Together, We Can… And Should

This year’s theme for Hair for Hope is “Together, We Can” — and it perfectly sums up Jason’s journey.

Through his efforts, Jason has not only supported children with cancer — he’s rallied a community, instilled lifelong values in his kids, and shown what it means to be an everyday hero.

“For anyone going through cancer, or who has a loved one battling it — you are not alone,” Jason says. “Your family is there for you. But beyond that, there’s a big community of people, like us, who are here to support you. We may not know you personally, but we stand with you.”

If Jason’s story moved you, maybe it’s time to take that leap yourself. Hair for Hope 2025 is more than just a campaign—it’s a national movement of solidarity, compassion, and courage.

Don’t worry about the bald head. Worry about the kind of impact you want to leave behind.

Because who knows? Maybe next year, it’ll be your story we’re sharing.

item.title: Everything You Need to Know About Fetal Macrosomia
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Explore the causes, risk factors, complications, and management strategies of fetal macrosomia, a condition where a baby is significantly larger than average at birth.
item.content:encoded:
Imagine preparing for the arrival of your baby, only to discover that your little one is expected to be significantly larger than average. This scenario is a reality for many expectant parents facing fetal macrosomia. It is a condition where a newborn weighs more than 8 pounds, 13 ounces (4,000 grams), regardless of gestational age.

While a chubby baby might seem adorable, fetal macrosomia can lead to complications for both mother and child during delivery and beyond.

Understanding the causes, risks, and management strategies is crucial for ensuring the health and safety of both.

What Is Fetal Macrosomia?

Fetal macrosomia refers to a condition where a baby is born with a weight exceeding 8 pounds, 13 ounces (4,000 grams). In some definitions, a weight over 9 pounds, 15 ounces (4,500 grams) is considered macrosomic.

This condition is distinct from “large for gestational age” (LGA), which considers the baby’s weight relative to the gestational age.

Causes and Risk Factors

Everything You Need to Know About Fetal Macrosomia

Maternal Factors:

Diabetes: Both pre-existing diabetes and gestational diabetes can lead to increased fetal growth due to higher glucose levels.

Obesity: Excessive maternal weight before or during pregnancy can increase the risk.

Excessive Weight Gain: Gaining more weight than recommended during pregnancy can contribute to fetal macrosomia.

Previous Macrosomic Baby: Having delivered a large baby in the past increases the likelihood in subsequent pregnancies.

Post-term Pregnancy: Pregnancies extending beyond 40 weeks can result in larger babies.

Fetal Factors:

Genetics: Family history can play a role in determining baby’s size.

Male Sex: Male babies are statistically more likely to be larger at birth.

Certain Medical Conditions: Conditions like Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome can lead to increased fetal growth.

Signs and Diagnosis

Diagnosing fetal macrosomia before birth can be challenging. Healthcare providers may use the following methods:

Ultrasound: Estimating fetal weight by measuring parts of the baby’s body.

Fundal Height Measurement: Measuring the distance from the pubic bone to the top of the uterus.

Physical Examination: Assessing the size and position of the baby through palpation.

It’s important to note that these methods are not always accurate, and the true weight of the baby is often only known after birth.

Potential Complications For the Mother:

Prolonged Labor: A larger baby can lead to longer labor durations.

Cesarean Delivery: Increased likelihood of requiring a C-section.

Birth Canal Injuries: Higher risk of perineal tears and postpartum hemorrhage.

For the Baby:

Shoulder Dystocia: Difficulty delivering the baby’s shoulders after the head has emerged.

Birth Injuries: Risk of fractures or nerve damage during delivery.

Low Blood Sugar: Hypoglycemia shortly after birth.

Childhood Obesity: Higher risk of obesity and metabolic syndrome later in life.

Management and Treatment Options

Everything You Need to Know About Fetal Macrosomia

Prenatal Management:

Monitoring: Regular ultrasounds to track fetal growth.

Blood Sugar Control: Managing maternal glucose levels through diet, exercise, or medication.

Weight Management: Ensuring appropriate weight gain during pregnancy.

Delivery Planning:

Mode of Delivery: Deciding between vaginal birth and cesarean delivery based on estimated fetal weight and maternal health.

Timing: Considering early induction if the baby is growing rapidly.

Postnatal Care:

Monitoring Baby’s Health: Checking for hypoglycemia and other complications.

Maternal Recovery: Addressing any birth injuries or complications experienced by the mother.

Prevention Strategies

Preconception Counseling: Managing chronic conditions like diabetes before pregnancy.

Healthy Lifestyle: Maintaining a balanced diet and regular exercise during pregnancy.

Regular Prenatal Visits: Monitoring fetal growth and maternal health consistently.

Fetal macrosomia is a condition that requires careful monitoring and management to ensure the safety of both mother and child. By understanding the risk factors and working closely with healthcare providers, expectant parents can navigate this challenge effectively.

Early detection, appropriate planning, and postnatal care are key components in managing fetal macrosomia and promoting healthy outcomes.

item.title: What You Need To Know About Obstetric Fistula
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Explore the causes, symptoms, and treatments of obstetric fistula, a preventable childbirth injury affecting women worldwide. Learn about prevention strategies and available support systems.
item.content:encoded:
Childbirth should be a moment of joy, yet for thousands of women especially in low-resource settings, it becomes a source of lifelong suffering due to a preventable injury known as obstetric fistula. This condition not only leads to chronic physical discomfort and incontinence, but also strips women of their dignity, often resulting in social isolation, depression, and economic hardship.

Despite being nearly eliminated in high-income countries, obstetric fistula remains a widespread issue in parts of Africa, Asia, and the Middle East, underscoring a profound global health disparity.

This article explores the underlying causes, signs, treatment options, and global efforts aimed at eradicating this devastating condition once and for all.

What is Obstetric Fistula?

Obstetric fistula is an abnormal connection between a woman’s genital tract and her urinary tract or rectum, typically resulting from prolonged obstructed labor. The pressure from the baby’s head during extended labor can cut off blood flow to the surrounding tissues, causing them to die and creating a hole. This condition is most prevalent in regions with limited access to quality maternal healthcare.

Types of Obstetric Fistula

Vesicovaginal Fistula (VVF): An opening between the bladder and the vagina, leading to continuous urinary incontinence.

Rectovaginal Fistula (RVF): An opening between the rectum and the vagina, resulting in fecal incontinence.

Combined Fistula: Involves both urinary and fecal incontinence due to multiple openings.

Causes and Risk Factors

What You Need To Know About Obstetric Fistula

Prolonged Obstructed Labor

The primary cause of obstetric fistula is prolonged obstructed labor, where the baby cannot pass through the birth canal due to its size or the mother’s pelvic structure. Without timely medical intervention, such as a cesarean section, the sustained pressure can lead to tissue necrosis and fistula formation.

Lack of Access to Quality Maternal Healthcare

In many low-resource settings, women lack access to skilled birth attendants and emergency obstetric care. This deficiency increases the risk of complications during childbirth, including fistula development.

Early Marriage and Teenage Pregnancy

Young girls who marry and become pregnant before their bodies are fully developed are at higher risk of obstructed labor, leading to a greater likelihood of fistula.

Malnutrition

Poor nutrition can result in stunted growth and underdeveloped pelvises in women, making childbirth more difficult and increasing the risk of obstructed labor and fistula.

Symptoms and Diagnosis Common Symptoms

Continuous Leakage: Involuntary leakage of urine or feces through the vagina.

Foul-Smelling Discharge: Persistent, unpleasant-smelling vaginal discharge.

Recurrent Infections: Frequent urinary tract or vaginal infections.

Skin Irritation: Irritation and sores in the genital area due to constant wetness.

Social Isolation: Withdrawal from social interactions due to embarrassment and stigma.

Diagnostic Procedures

Physical Examination: A thorough pelvic exam to identify any abnormal openings.

Dye Tests: Introducing a dye into the bladder to observe any leakage into the vagina, confirming a fistula.

Imaging Tests: Utilizing imaging techniques like fistulograms to determine the fistula’s size and location.

Treatment Option

What You Need To Know About Obstetric Fistula

Surgical Interventions

Surgical repair is the primary treatment for obstetric fistula. The procedure involves closing the abnormal opening and restoring normal function. Success rates vary, with studies indicating closure rates ranging from 77.85% to 88.1%, depending on various factors, including the fistula’s complexity and the patient’s overall health. Post-operative care is crucial to ensure healing and prevent recurrence.

Non-Surgical Support

Counseling: Providing psychological support to help women cope with the trauma and stigma associated with fistula.

Reintegration Programs: Assisting women in returning to their communities through education and vocational training.

Physical Therapy: Rehabilitation exercises to strengthen pelvic muscles and improve continence.

Prevention Strategies Improving Maternal Healthcare

Ensuring access to quality maternal healthcare is vital. This includes:

Skilled Birth Attendants: Training and deploying healthcare professionals to assist during childbirth.

Emergency Obstetric Care: Establishing facilities equipped to handle childbirth complications.

Antenatal Care: Regular check-ups during pregnancy to monitor the mother’s and baby’s health.

Community Education

Educating communities about the importance of maternal health can lead to:

Delayed Marriages: Encouraging girls to marry and conceive at a mature age.

Nutrition Awareness: Promoting proper nutrition for girls and women.

Health-Seeking Behavior: Encouraging women to seek medical care during pregnancy and childbirth.

Obstetric fistula remains a significant public health issue, particularly in low-resource settings. However, with concerted efforts focusing on prevention, timely treatment, and community support, it is a condition that can be eradicated.

Empowering women through education, improving access to quality maternal healthcare, and supporting affected individuals are crucial steps toward a fistula-free world.

Symptoms and Diagnosis
Common Symptoms

Continuous Leakage: Involuntary leakage of urine or feces through the vagina.

Foul-Smelling Discharge: Persistent, unpleasant-smelling vaginal discharge.

Recurrent Infections: Frequent urinary tract or vaginal infections.

Skin Irritation: Irritation and sores in the genital area due to constant wetness.

Social Isolation: Withdrawal from social interactions due to embarrassment and stigma.

Diagnostic Procedures

Physical Examination: A thorough pelvic exam to identify any abnormal openings.

Dye Tests: Introducing a dye into the bladder to observe any leakage into the vagina, confirming a fistula.

Imaging Tests: Utilizing imaging techniques like fistulograms to determine the fistula's size and location.

Treatment Option

Surgical Interventions
Surgical repair is the primary treatment for obstetric fistula. The procedure involves closing the abnormal opening and restoring normal function. Success rates vary, with studies indicating closure rates ranging from 77.85% to 88.1%, depending on various factors, including the fistula's complexity and the patient's overall health. Post-operative care is crucial to ensure healing and prevent recurrence.
Non-Surgical Support

Counseling: Providing psychological support to help women cope with the trauma and stigma associated with fistula.

Reintegration Programs: Assisting women in returning to their communities through education and vocational training.

Physical Therapy: Rehabilitation exercises to strengthen pelvic muscles and improve continence.

Prevention Strategies
Improving Maternal Healthcare
Ensuring access to quality maternal healthcare is vital. This includes:

Skilled Birth Attendants: Training and deploying healthcare professionals to assist during childbirth.

Emergency Obstetric Care: Establishing facilities equipped to handle childbirth complications.

Antenatal Care: Regular check-ups during pregnancy to monitor the mother's and baby's health.

Community Education
Educating communities about the importance of maternal health can lead to:

Delayed Marriages: Encouraging girls to marry and conceive at a mature age.

Nutrition Awareness: Promoting proper nutrition for girls and women.

Health-Seeking Behavior: Encouraging women to seek medical care during pregnancy and childbirth.


Obstetric fistula remains a significant public health issue, particularly in low-resource settings. However, with concerted efforts focusing on prevention, timely treatment, and community support, it is a condition that can be eradicated.
Empowering women through education, improving access to quality maternal healthcare, and supporting affected individuals are crucial steps toward a fistula-free world.

item.dc:creator: Gio Adriano
item.description: Over the past several months, Punggol residents have faced an unexpected challenge—monkey intrusions. With over 200 incidents reported within just seven months, the community is on high alert, especially parents concerned for their children’s safety. item.content:encoded:
Over the past several months, Punggol residents have faced an unexpected challenge—monkey intrusions. With over 200 incidents reported within just seven months, the community is on high alert, especially parents concerned for their children’s safety. These encounters, often involving long-tailed macaques, are more than mere inconveniences—they’re disrupting routines, scaring kids, and exposing gaps in home safety.

Why Are Monkeys Entering Residential Areas?

Rapid urban development has pushed monkeys out of their habitats, while human activities like feeding or leaving food exposed encourage them to explore homes.

With forested zones replaced by high-rise developments, monkeys have lost access to their usual food sources. The lure of open windows, food scraps, and even toys mimicking snacks drives them to explore human dwellings. Feeding monkeys, whether intentional or not, reinforces this behavior and escalates encounters.

What Kind of Monkeys Are Involved?

The long-tailed macaques are the species most commonly seen around Punggol and are known for their intelligence, curiosity, and adaptability.

Long-tailed macaques are highly adaptive and intelligent primates. Their curiosity, combined with memory and social learning, makes them quick to identify accessible homes and revisit those with food rewards. These monkeys are not inherently aggressive but can become bold when accustomed to human presence.

How to Monkey-Proof Your Home Simple, Effective Home Modifications

Install grilles, locks, and netting on windows and balconies to block entry. Motion-sensor devices and visual deterrents can also help reduce visits.

Install window grilles, child-safe latches, and mesh screens, especially on windows or balconies adjacent to green spaces. Motion-sensor alarms or deterrents like reflective tape or ultrasonic devices can reduce repeat visits from familiar monkeys.

Daily Habits That Prevent Intrusions

Secure food and baby items out of sight, and avoid actions that can unintentionally attract or reward monkey behavior.

Keep all food out of sight—fruit bowls, leftovers, snacks, and even empty wrappers. Refrain from feeding monkeys, even accidentally. Avoid leaving baby bottles or lunch boxes near doors or windows. Store outdoor items like strollers or diaper bags indoors.

Helping Children Cope with Monkey Encounters Emotional Impact on Kids

Children may feel afraid after a monkey intrusion and need reassurance, validation, and open conversations to feel safe again.

Children might develop fears of being alone or near balconies and windows. They may express these fears as nightmares, anxiety, or resistance to playing in familiar spaces. Open communication is essential—listen and acknowledge their fears without dismissing them.

Teaching Safety Without Instilling Fear

Turn the experience into a teachable moment by promoting respectful behavior and safety without causing unnecessary fear.

Turn the incident into a learning opportunity. Teach kids about the importance of boundaries and respecting animals. Reinforce safe practices like not leaving food out and alerting adults if they see monkeys nearby.

Extra Protection for Babies and Toddlers Safe Space Layout Tips

Reorganize baby and toddler areas to avoid exposure near open windows, and ensure furnishings help keep little ones secure.

If your child’s play or sleep area is near open windows, consider rearranging furniture to place cribs or playpens further away. Add high latches to reduce unsupervised access.

Must-Have Safety Features

Use netting, locks, and visual blockers to prevent monkey access and keep baby items hidden from view.

Install mesh netting on windows, especially in nurseries. Ensure baby bottles, toys, and snack items are not visible from outside. This reduces the chance of monkeys being attracted to your child’s area.

When to Call for Help Handling Aggressive or Persistent Monkeys

Never attempt to confront or scare off monkeys yourself. Contact authorities for safe and legal removal.

Do not confront or try to scare monkeys away yourself. Aggressive gestures may provoke them. Maintain a safe distance, and keep doors and windows closed until help arrives.

Contact Numbers

Save and use these emergency contacts to get quick help for monkey-related issues in Punggol.

NParks 24-Hour Animal Response Centre: 📞 1800-476-1600

ACRES Wildlife Rescue Hotline: 📞 9783-7782 (7am–1am daily)

FAQs Are monkey encounters in Punggol dangerous?

While not typically dangerous, monkeys can become aggressive if they feel threatened. Avoid direct confrontation and contact animal authorities when needed.

What attracts monkeys to homes?

Visible food, toys resembling food, and baby items are common attractions. Even the scent of food can draw monkeys.

Can I legally feed monkeys in Singapore?

No, feeding monkeys is illegal and poses risks to both humans and animals. It encourages dependency and aggressive behavior.

What are the penalties for feeding wildlife?

Offenders can be fined up to $5,000 under Singapore’s Wildlife Act for feeding wild animals.

How can I talk to my child about monkey encounters?

Use calm, informative language. Emphasize safety and boundaries while helping them appreciate animals from a distance.

item.title: Lingering Gastrointestinal Issues (GI) in Children Post-COVID-19: What Parents Need to Know
item.dc:creator: Gio Adriano
item.description: As the global community continues to navigate the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, emerging research highlights a growing concern: children recovering from COVID-19 may experience lingering gastrointestinal (GI) issues. Known as part of post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 infection (PASC), these symptoms can persist for months, impacting children’s quality of life and posing challenges for parents […]
item.content:encoded:
As the global community continues to navigate the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, emerging research highlights a growing concern: children recovering from COVID-19 may experience lingering gastrointestinal (GI) issues. Known as part of post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 infection (PASC), these symptoms can persist for months, impacting children’s quality of life and posing challenges for parents and caregivers.

Understanding Post-COVID-19 Gastrointestinal Symptoms in Children

Post-COVID-19 GI symptoms in children are becoming increasingly documented in clinical settings. Commonly reported issues include:

Abdominal pain

Diarrhea

Nausea and vomiting

Constipation

Bloating

Indigestion

Recent studies show that children who have contracted COVID-19 are at a higher risk of developing such GI symptoms compared to those who have not been infected. While these symptoms can vary in severity, their persistence beyond the acute infection phase warrants medical attention and careful monitoring.

Potential Mechanisms Behind Lingering GI Issues Post-COVID-19

Understanding why these symptoms persist involves exploring how the virus interacts with the body:

ACE2 Receptors in the Gut: SARS-CoV-2 targets ACE2 receptors, which are abundantly present in the intestinal lining, , causing inflammation and discomfort.

Disrupted good bacteria: COVID-19 may alter the gut microbiota, leading to imbalances that contribute to chronic GI symptoms and affect overall immune function.

Leaky Gut Syndrome: The virus can compromise intestinal barrier integrity, allowing harmful substances to pass into the bloodstream, further fueling systemic inflammation and discomfort.

GI Long-Term Implications and Risks

Left unaddressed, lingering GI symptoms may evolve into more chronic conditions, including:

Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS): long-term tummy pain

Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD): Problems like acid reflux (heartburn)

Functional Gastrointestinal Disorders (FGIDs): Irritable bowel symptoms (frequent pain, constipation, or diarrhea)

Moreover, children who experienced moderate to severe COVID-19 are at a heightened risk of prolonged GI distress. This highlights the necessity for ongoing health evaluations even after visible recovery.

GI Management and Treatment Strategies

Timely and proactive treatment can significantly improve outcomes:

Early Medical Evaluation: Parents should not dismiss persistent GI complaints. A paediatrician can conduct necessary diagnostics and recommend appropriate therapies.

Dietary Adjustments: A balanced, anti-inflammatory diet rich in fibre, fluids, and probiotics can help restore gut health.

Supportive Therapies: Use of probiotics, antacids, or anti-diarrheal medications may be advised depending on specific symptoms.

Behavioural support may also be needed to help children cope with chronic discomfort and its psychological impact.

GI Preventive Measures and Recommendations

Prevention remains the best strategy for protecting children’s long-term health:

Vaccination: Ensuring children are vaccinated against COVID-19 significantly reduces the risk of both acute and long-term complications.

Monitoring After Recovery: Regular follow-ups with healthcare providers can catch and treat emerging issues early.

Parental Awareness: Parents should document and communicate any ongoing symptoms post-COVID-19 to their child’s doctor for timely intervention.

Why Ongoing GI Monitoring Matters for Children After COVID-19

While most children recover fully from COVID-19, some experience a longer journey marked by gastrointestinal discomfort and disruption. These symptoms, though sometimes subtle, can evolve into more serious issues if not carefully managed. By remaining vigilant and proactive—through timely healthcare, nutritional support, and follow-up care—parents can play a critical role in ensuring their child’s recovery is complete, healthy, and resilient.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

1. What are the signs that my child may be experiencing post-COVID-19 GI issues?

Persistent abdominal pain, diarrhoea, nausea, constipation, and loss of appetite beyond the acute illness phase could signal lingering effects.

2. How long can GI symptoms persist in children after recovering from COVID-19?

Symptoms may last several weeks to months. In some cases, they may become chronic if not addressed.

3. Are there specific treatments available for post-COVID-19 GI symptoms in children?

Yes, treatments may include dietary adjustments, medications, and supportive therapies tailored to the child’s symptoms.

4. Can COVID-19 vaccination help prevent long-term GI complications in children?

Vaccination lowers the risk of severe infection and subsequent complications, including GI issues.

5. When should I consult a healthcare provider about my child’s GI symptoms post-COVID-19?

If symptoms persist beyond a few weeks or significantly impact your child’s daily activities, seek medical advice promptly.

item.title: Breastfeeding and RTIs: New Study Finds It Lowers Infection Risks
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Discover how breastfeeding can help protect your baby from respiratory tract infections (RTIs), reduce hospitalizations, and boost their immune system from day one.
item.content:encoded:
Respiratory tract infections (RTIs) are one of the most common health concerns for babies and young children. From the sniffles to serious hospital stays, RTIs can take a toll, not just on children, but on their families too.

While medical care is always important, prevention is still the best first line of defense, especially for little ones. And one of the most powerful, natural ways to protect your baby? Breastfeeding.

Why Are RTIs a Big Deal?

Breastfeeding and RTIs: How Your Milk Shields Your Baby From Illness

RTIs affect the nose, throat, airways, and lungs. They can range from mild colds to more serious conditions like bronchiolitis or pneumonia. For babies under 2 years old, these infections can lead to:

Difficulty breathing

High fevers

Hospitalization

Long-term respiratory issues

Because a baby’s immune system is still developing, they’re especially vulnerable during their first year of life.

The Invisible Shield: How Breastfeeding Helps

Breastmilk isn’t just food. It’s a living substance packed with antibodies, white blood cells, and nutrients that help fight off viruses and bacteria.

A recent study found that babies who were exclusively breastfed for 6 months and continued to be breastfed up to 1 year had:

34% lower risk of respiratory infections

59% lower risk of lower RTIs

88% lower risk of hospitalization due to RTIs

Compared to formula-fed babies, the difference is significant.

What Makes Breastmilk So Powerful?

Breastfeeding and RTIs: How Your Milk Shields Your Baby From Illness

Breastmilk contains:

Immunoglobulin A (IgA) – creates a protective layer on mucous membranes in the throat, nose, and intestines

White blood cells – directly fight off infections

Prebiotics and probiotics – support a healthy gut, where much of the immune system lives

Tailored antibodies – your body customizes these based on germs you’re exposed to, giving your baby hyper-local protection

And the best part? The longer you breastfeed, the stronger and longer-lasting these benefits become.

What If Breastfeeding Is Hard?

Breastfeeding isn’t always smooth sailing. Some moms face low milk supply, latching issues, or physical exhaustion. If you’re struggling:

Reach out to a lactation consultant

Ask your pediatrician for guidance

Lean on your support system

Every drop of breastmilk still counts. Even a few weeks of breastfeeding can offer health benefits that last far beyond infancy.

Protect What Matters Most

As parents, we’d do anything to keep our children safe, and breastfeeding is one of the simplest yet most powerful ways to do that. It’s more than just nourishment; it’s your baby’s first line of defense against illness.

Even a few weeks of breastfeeding can make a lasting difference. So if you can breastfeed, know that you’re giving your little one more than a meal. You’re giving your little one protection, comfort, and love straight from the heart.

Even a few weeks of breastfeeding can make a lasting difference. So if you can breastfeed, know that you’re giving your little one more than a meal. You're giving your little one protection, comfort, and love straight from the heart.

item.content:encoded:
On Sunday, 1 June 2025, Singapore will come together to celebrate its 60th year of independence with the Peace and Prosperity Singapura SG60 Walkathon (PPSG SG60 Walkathon). Organised by Tao One Care Ltd, this event not only marks the nation’s milestone but also commemorates Tao One’s 10th anniversary. The walkathon aims to set a new Singapore record by displaying 60 giant flags, each adorned with Chinese blessing phrases symbolising the nation’s journey of prosperity and harmony.

The event will be graced by former President Madam Halimah Yacob, who will serve as the Guest of Honour, leading participants in a 5km walk that showcases Singapore’s multicultural spirit.

A Symbol of Harmony — What the Walkathon Represents

The PPSG Walkathon, first inaugurated in 2019 during Singapore’s Bicentennial, has been a platform for celebrating the nation’s multiculturalism and social cohesion. With over 2,500 participants from diverse racial and religious backgrounds in its inaugural event, the walkathon emphasised the strength found in unity. This year’s edition continues that legacy, reflecting on Singapore’s development over the past six decades and promoting a message of peace and prosperity.

Key Highlights of the 2025 PPSG SG60 Walkathon Setting a New Singapore Record

A central feature of the 2025 walkathon is the display of 60 giant flags, each featuring Chinese blessing phrases. These flags, sponsored by over 50 individuals and organisations, symbolise Singapore’s growth and the collective aspirations of its people. The display aims to set a new national record, underscoring the event’s significance.

Multicultural Performances

Participants will be treated to a variety of traditional performances, including Malay Kompang and Indian drum ensembles. These performances highlight Singapore’s rich cultural tapestry and the harmonious coexistence of its diverse communities.

Commemorative Souvenir Packs

All registered participants will receive a goodie bag containing an event T-shirt, an umbrella, a water bottle, and refreshments. These souvenirs serve as mementoes of the occasion and symbolise the unity and spirit of the nation.

The 5km Walking Route

The walkathon will commence at imPAct@Hong Lim Green and conclude at Marina Barrage, covering a 5km route that passes several of Singapore’s iconic landmarks. This journey not only offers participants a chance to engage in a healthy activity but also to reflect on the nation’s progress and the importance of unity.

Distinguished Supporters and Co-Organisers

The event is co-organised by several esteemed organisations, including the Singapore Wushu and Dragon Lion Dance Federation, the International Long Shi Trading Hub, and Jack Neo’s PaPaZao. Support is also provided by the Harmony Circle of Sembawang GRC, Scam Public Education Office (SPEO), M3@Jurong, PPIS, and the Singapore Hadrah and Kompang Association (PEHAKS). Their collaboration underscores the collective effort to promote social cohesion and cultural appreciation.

Tao One Care Ltd — Driving Social Impact in Singapore

Established in 2024, Tao One Care Ltd serves as the secular social service branch of Tao One Ltd, focusing on community service, cultural heritage, and humanitarian work. Among its notable initiatives are:

Project 3E: Empowering Education for Everyone: In partnership with UNHCR, this project supports 30 refugee learning centres in Malaysia, primarily serving the Rohingya community.

Safe Sound Sleeping Places (S3P): Launched in 2020, this initiative has assisted over 100 homeless individuals in reintegrating into society, earning accolades such as the “Friend of MSF” award and the President’s Certificate of Commendation (COVID-19).

Mobile Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) Clinics: Providing healthcare services to over 7,000 patients in the Southeast District, with plans to open a new branch in Bedok South in May 2025.

Rehabilitation Programmes: Collaborating with the Singapore Prison Service to aid inmate reintegration.

Pro Bono Funeral Services: Offering services regardless of race or religion, and working closely with organisations like the National Kidney Foundation and Singapore Cheshire Home to provide employment opportunities for persons with disabilities.

SG60 Walkathon Event Details & How to Participate

Date: Sunday, 1 June 2025

Time: Registration from 2:30 PM; Walkathon flag-off at 5:30 PM

Location: Start at imPAct@Hong Lim Green, end at Marina Barrage

Registration: Visit TaoOne.org or their Facebook page.

Walk with Purpose, Celebrate with Pride

The PPSG SG60 Walkathon 2025 is more than a commemorative event — it is a living tribute to Singapore’s resilience, unity, and vibrant multicultural identity. From the inspiring presence of former President Madam Halimah Yacob to the striking display of 60 symbolic flags, this walkathon encapsulates the spirit of a nation that thrives on harmony and shared values.

Whether you’re joining to set a national record, embrace cultural performances, or simply walk in the name of peace and progress, your presence matters. Every step echoes the voices of generations who built Singapore’s past — and those who will shape its future.

Let us walk together, celebrating our shared journey and stepping boldly into the next chapter of Singapore’s story.
